item.title: Obama Says Cuba Embargo Does ‘Not Serve Our Interests’
item.description: In remarks in Havana, Mr. Obama said there were steps that Cuba could take, especially on human rights, that would help to persuade Congress to lift the embargo.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba addressed reporters Monday.

item.title: Belgian Police Name Man Suspected of Being Salah Abdeslam’s Accomplice
item.description: Najim Laachraoui was with Mr. Abdeslam, who is charged with terrorist murder over the Paris attacks, as they passed between Hungary and Austria in September.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.media:description: A fake identity card in the name of Soufiane Kayal. A man using that name rented a house in the town of Auvelais, about 33 miles south of Brussels, that was searched by the police on Nov. 26.

item.title: Congolese Politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, Is Convicted of War Crimes
item.description: Mr. Bemba led a militia that committed rape and murder in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003, the International Criminal Court found.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Jean-Pierre Bemba, center, at the International Criminal Court on Monday in The Hague.

item.title: Boaty McBoatface: What You Get When You Let the Internet Decide
item.description: A proposal by a British agency to let the Internet name a research ship is the latest in a trend of web users having some fun with public polls.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: A computer image of the research vessel, which is still being designed and is scheduled to set sail in 2019.

item.title: Letter From Europe: France Takes a Back Seat to Germany in E.U. Migrant Crisis
item.description: The French appear to be losing ground as a voice to be reckoned with in Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France greeting Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at the Élysée Palace in Paris on March 4.

item.title: A View of ISIS’s Evolution in New Details of Paris Attacks
item.description: A 55-page French report details how the attackers used disciplined communications, identified soft targets and perfected bomb-making techniques after two years of failures.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI, ALISSA J. RUBIN and LAURE FOURQUET
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated at the Bataclan concert hall during the Paris attacks in November. Investigators hope the arrest of Salah Abdeslam will shed new light on the assaults.

item.title: ‘War of the Worlds’ Shape-Shifts Onto the London Stage
item.description: This stage production, whose team includes the album’s writer, cranks up the excess of “Jeff Wayne’s Musical Version of the War of the Worlds.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA
item.media:description: From left, Jimmy Nail, Heidi Range and Michael Praed in “The War of the Worlds,” which has been adapted for the West End stage in London.

item.title: 19 Yemeni Jews Arrive in Israel, Ending Secret Rescue Operation
item.description: They came from an ancient and once-vibrant group that became increasingly imperiled by violence and war.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Arielle Di-Porto/The Jewish Agency for Israel
item.media:description: A final group of Jewish immigrants from Yemen arrived in Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Beijing Journal: Breathing Life Into Spaces Well Beyond 6 Feet Under Beijing’s Streets
item.description: A start-up that turns unused basements into community centers wants to reimagine the future of the city’s underground spaces — many of them former bomb shelters.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparations for an art exhibition at the Digua Shequ community center, in a former Beijing bomb shelter.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Long Shadow of Argentina’s Dictatorship
item.description: President Obama’s visit on the 40th anniversary of a brutal military coup has reopened old wounds.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: UKI GOÑI

item.title: China’s Coast Guard Rams Fishing Boat to Free It From Indonesian Authorities
item.description: The boat was stopped for fishing illegally and was being towed to port when the Chinese took it back, prompting Jakarta to summon the Chinese ambassador to a meeting.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: The foreign minister of Indonesia, Retno Marsudi, in the country’s capital, Jakarta, on Monday. She handed over an official letter of protest about the confrontation in the South China Sea to the minister counselor of China’s Embassy.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Cuba Heads for Miami
item.description: A revolution is not a bed of roses. Nor is the end of the revolution.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: In One-Party Vietnam, Independents Vie for Assembly Seats
item.description: A group of around two dozen activists and celebrities, more than in years past, are running as independents for the country’s rubber-stamp National Assembly.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.media:credit: Quinn Ryan Mattingly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mai Khoi, 32, a singer-songwriter, is among around two dozen Vietnamese activists and celebrities who are running as independents this month for the authoritarian state’s rubber-stamp National Assembly. Above her piano hangs a poster for her campaign.

item.title: Sinosphere: China Says It Found Ring Said to Sell Improperly Stored Vaccines
item.description: The police say they are searching in dozens of provinces for 300 people involved in the illegal sales beginning in 2010.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A polio vaccine was tested at a government lab in Kunming, China, last year. Over a dozen suspect products have been identified, including vaccines for rabies, polio, meningitis, hepatitis B and mumps, officials in the Chinese province of Shandong said.

item.title: Stay or Go? Cuban Entrepreneurs Divided on Where to Stake Futures
item.description: While many leave for the United States, business owners opting to remain are creating an expanding class, optimistic despite serious challenges.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonio, center background, and Sandra Camacho Rodríguez, to his right, named their bakery in Havana the Burner Brothers, a reference to all the cookies they burned on their way to opening the shop.

item.title: North Korea Launches Short-Range Projectiles, Seoul Says
item.description: The projectiles, launched from the east coast, landed in the sea between the Korean Peninsula and Japan, the South Korean military said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: The Artist Zhang Hongtu on Appropriating Mao’s Image
item.description: Mr. Zhang discusses his early embrace of Mao’s teachings, his family’s tribulations and what he hoped his art would accomplish.
item.dc:creator: PAN GE
item.media:credit: Regina Kokoszka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zhang Hongtu, in his studio in the Woodside neighborhood of Queens, before his work “Soy Book.”

item.title: Q. And A.: The Culture of Rape Within ISIS, and the Questions That Arise
item.description: Excerpts from a live discussion concerning the systematic rape and sexual slavery of Yazidi women and young girls held captive by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former sex slave of different Islamic State men, right, wept as she said goodbye to her aunt before leaving Iraq for Germany.

item.title: As Obama Arrives, Cuba Tightens Grip on Dissent
item.description: Cuba, a police state working out how much to open up to the world and to its own people, has gone above and beyond to prevent embarrassing surprises.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: A member of the Ladies in White dissident group being carried by officers after the police broke up a demonstration by the group.

item.title: Cubans Pack the Streets for a Glimpse of President Obama
item.description: The president’s visit, the first by an American leader in nearly nine decades, holds the potential to exorcise one of the last ghosts of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: The president and Michelle Obama in Old Havana on Sunday.
